panels.description: Apdex is a measure of requests that complete within a tolerable period of time for the service. Higher is better.

panels.title: patroni-ci Service Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_5m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_30m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_6h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.title: pgbouncer SLI RPS - Requests per Second

panels.content:
### Description

All transactions destined for the Postgres secondary instances are routed through the pgbouncer instances
running on the patroni nodes themselves. This SLI models those transactions in aggregate.

Error rate uses mtail metrics from pgbouncer logs.



### Observability Tools

* [üìñ Kibana: pgbouncer logs](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/kibana#/discover?_a=(columns:!(json.hostname,json.pg_message),filters:!((meta:(index:'97f04200-024b-11eb-81e5-155ba78758d4',key:json.type.keyword,params:'patroni-ci',type:phrase),query:(match:(json.type.keyword:(query:'patroni-ci',type:phrase)))),(meta:(index:'97f04200-024b-11eb-81e5-155ba78758d4',key:json.tag.keyword,params:postgres.pgbouncer,type:phrase),query:(match:(json.tag.keyword:(query:postgres.pgbouncer,type:phrase)))),(meta:(index:'97f04200-024b-11eb-81e5-155ba78758d4',key:json.type,params:'patroni-ci',type:phrase),query:(match:(json.type:(query:'patroni-ci',type:phrase))))),index:'97f04200-024b-11eb-81e5-155ba78758d4')&_g=(time:(from:'${__from:date:iso}',to:'${__to:date:iso}')))

panels.title: rails_primary_sql SLI RPS - Requests per Second

panels.content:
### Description

Represents all SQL transactions issued through ActiveRecord from the Rails monolith (web, api, websockets, but not sidekiq) to the Postgres primary.
Durations can be impacted by various conditions other than Patroni, including client pool saturation, pgbouncer saturation,
Ruby thread contention and network conditions.

Durations can be impacted by various conditions other than Patroni, including client pool saturation, pgbouncer saturation,
Ruby thread contention and network conditions.

panels.content:
### Description

Represents all SQL transactions issued to the primary Postgres instance.
Errors represent transaction rollbacks.

panels.description: Error rates are a measure of unhandled service exceptions per second. Client errors are excluded when possible. Lower is better

seriesOverrides.alias: /6h Degradation SLO \(5% of monthly error budget\).*/
/1h Outage SLO \(2% of monthly error budget\).*/

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: transactions_replica SLI Error Ratio

targets.expr:
sum (
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="transactions_replica",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_5m{component="transactions_replica",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="transactions_replica",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"})),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="transactions_replica",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="transactions_replica",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"})),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_30m{component="transactions_replica",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="transactions_replica",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"})),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_6h{component="transactions_replica",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="transactions_replica",monitor="global",type="patroni-ci"})),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.description: The operation rate is the sum total of all requests being handle for all components within this service. Note that a single user request can lead to requests to multiple components. Higher is busier.
panels.title: transactions_replica SLI RPS - Requests per Second

panels.content:
### Description

Represents all SQL transactions issued to replica Postgres instances, in aggregate.
Errors represent transaction rollbacks.



### Observability Tools

panels.title: disk_sustained_read_throughput component saturation: Disk Sustained Read Throughput Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Gitaly runs on Google Cloud's Persistent Disk product. This has a published sustained
maximum write IOPS value. This value can be exceeded for brief periods.

If a single node is consistently reaching saturation, it may indicate a noisy-neighbour repository,
possible abuse or it may indicate that the node needs rebalancing.

More information can be found at
https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/performance.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:

      /
      node_disk_max_write_iops{device!="sda", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}

      1)
  ,
  0)
)

,0)

panels.title: memory component saturation: Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Netfilter connection tracking table utilization per node.

When saturated, new connection attempts (incoming SYN packets) are dropped with no reply, leaving clients to slowly retry (and typically fail again) over the next several seconds.  When packets are being dropped due to this condition, kernel will log the event as: "nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet".
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max_over_time(node_nf_conntrack_entries{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[1m])
      /
      node_nf_conntrack_entries_limit{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.description:
Measures the amount of scheduler waiting time that processes are waiting
to be scheduled, according to [`CPU Scheduling Metrics`](https://www.robustperception.io/cpu-scheduling-metrics-from-the-node-exporter).

A high value indicates that a node has more processes to be run than CPU time available
to handle them, and may lead to degraded responsiveness and performance from the application.

Additionally, it may indicate that the fleet is under-provisioned.
 Lower is better.

clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg without (cpu) (rate(node_schedstat_waiting_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[1h]))
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

panels.description:
This estimates the total bloat in Postgres Btree indexes, as a percentage of total index size.

IMPORTANT: bloat estimates are rough and depending on table/index structure, can be off for individual indexes,

      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

panels.title: pg_btree_bloat component saturation: Postgres btree bloat

panels.description:
This measures used int4 columns capacity in all postgres tables. It is critically important that we do not reach
saturation on primary key columns as GitLab will stop to work at this point.

The saturation point tracks all integer columns, so also foreign keys that might not match their source.

IID columns are deliberatly ignored because they are scoped to a project/namespace.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, column_name) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, column_name) (
        pg_int4_saturation_current_largest_value{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci",column_name!~".+(.|-|_)iid"} / pg_int4_saturation_column_max_value{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci",column_name!~".+(.|-|_)iid"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (avg_over_time(gitlab_database_bloat_table_bloat_size{job="gitlab-monitor-database-bloat", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[58m]))
      /
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (avg_over_time(gitlab_database_bloat_table_real_size{job="gitlab-monitor-database-bloat", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[58m]))

panels.title: pg_table_bloat component saturation: Postgres Table Bloat

panels.description:
This saturation metric measures the capacity of the Postgres primary instance to perform autovacuum operations
on all tables.

It measures the total time spent in vacuum operations, over a 24 hour period divided the maximum number of autovacuum processes
to give the total vacuum activity, in seconds. This value is divided by the TXID wraparound horizon for the database to
produce a percentage.

This value will approach 100% as two situation occur:

1. The amount of time spent performing autovacuum operations goes up, due to high dead-tuple generation in the database.
1. The write transaction volume goes up, decreasing the wraparound horizon.

If the total time spent vacuuming approached the wraparound time horizon, this would mean that the database would be at risk
of being unable to complete a vacuum of all tables within the wraparound time horizon. This would put the database at risk of XID
wraparound and immediate shutdown.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
          increase(fluentd_pg_auto_vacuum_elapsed_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[1d])
        )
        / on(environment, type) group_left() (
          pg_settings_autovacuum_max_workers and
          on (instance) pg_replication_is_replica == 0
        )
      )
      /
      (
        (2^31 - 10^6)
        /
        (
          avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
            deriv(pg_txid_current{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[1d]) and
            on (instance) pg_replication_is_replica == 0
          )
        )
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: pg_txid_vacuum_to_wraparound component saturation: Total autovacuum time to TXID wraparound horizon

panels.description:
This measures the total amount of time spent each day by autovacuum workers, as a percentage of total autovacuum capacity.

This resource uses the `auto_vacuum_elapsed_seconds` value logged by the autovacuum worker, and aggregates this across all
autovacuum jobs. In the case that there are 10 autovacuum workers, the total capacity is 10-days worth of autovacuum time per day.

Once the system is performing 10 days worth of autovacuum per day, the capacity will be saturated.

This resource is primarily intended to be used for long-term capacity planning.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        rate(fluentd_pg_auto_vacuum_elapsed_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[1d])
        and on (fqdn) (pg_replication_is_replica{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"} == 0)
      )
      /
      avg by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        pg_settings_autovacuum_max_workers{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}
        and on (instance, job) (pg_replication_is_replica{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"} == 0)
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: pg_vacuum_activity_v2 component saturation: Postgres Autovacuum Activity (non-sampled)

panels.description:
This saturation metric measures the total amount of time that the primary postgres instance is spending sending WAL segments
to replicas. It is expressed as a percentage of all CPU available on the primary postgres instance.

The more replicas connected, the higher this metric will be.

Since it's expressed as a percentage of all CPU, this should always remain low, since the CPU primarily needs to be available for
handling SQL statements.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        sum by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
          rate(namedprocess_namegroup_cpu_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci", groupname=~"pg.worker.walsender|pg.worker.walwriter|wal-g"}[5m])
          and on (fqdn) (pg_replication_is_replica{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"} == 0)
        )
        /
        count by (env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
          node_cpu_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci", mode="idle"} and on(fqdn) (pg_replication_is_replica{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"} == 0)
        )
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: pg_walsender_cpu component saturation: Walsender CPU Saturation

panels.description:
Risk of DB shutdown in the near future, approaching transaction ID wraparound.

This is a critical situation.

This saturation metric measures how close the database is to Transaction ID wraparound.

When wraparound occurs, the database will automatically shutdown to prevent data loss, causing a full outage.

Recovery would require entering single-user mode to run vacuum, taking the site down for a potentially multi-hour maintenance session.

To avoid reaching the db shutdown threshold, consider the following short-term actions:

1. Escalate to the SRE Datastores team, and then,

2. Find and terminate any very old transactions. The runbook for this alert has details.  Do this first.  It is the most critical step and may be all that is necessary to let autovacuum do its job.

3. Run a manual vacuum on tables with oldest relfrozenxid.  Manual vacuums run faster than autovacuum.

4. Add autovacuum workers or reduce autovacuum cost delay, if autovacuum is chronically unable to keep up with the transaction rate.

Long running transaction dashboard: https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/alerts-long_running_transactions/alerts-long-running-transactions?orgId=1
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, datname) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        max without (series) (
          label_replace(pg_database_wraparound_age_datfrozenxid{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}, "series", "datfrozenxid", "", "")
          or
          label_replace(pg_database_wraparound_age_datminmxid{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}, "series", "datminmxid", "", "")
        )
        and on (instance, job) (pg_replication_is_replica{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"} == 0)
      )
      /
      (2^31 - 10^6)
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: pg_xid_wraparound component saturation: Transaction ID Wraparound

panels.description:
pgbouncer async connection pool utilization per database node, for replica database connections.

Sidekiq maintains it's own pgbouncer connection pool. When this resource is saturated,
database operations may queue, leading to additional latency in background processing.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_pools_server_active_connections{user="gitlab", database="gitlabhq_production_sidekiq", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m]) +
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_pools_server_testing_connections{user="gitlab", database="gitlabhq_production_sidekiq", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m]) +
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_pools_server_used_connections{user="gitlab", database="gitlabhq_production_sidekiq", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m]) +
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_pools_server_login_connections{user="gitlab", database="gitlabhq_production_sidekiq", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m])
      )
      / on(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) group_left()
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) (
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_databases_pool_size{name="gitlabhq_production_sidekiq", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: pgbouncer_async_replica_pool component saturation: Postgres Async (Sidekiq) replica Connection Pool Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Client connections per pgbouncer process for Replicas connections.

pgbouncer is configured to use a `max_client_conn` setting. This limits the total number of client connections per pgbouncer.

When this limit is reached, client connections may be refused, and `max_client_conn` errors may appear in the pgbouncer logs.

This could affect users as Rails clients are left unable to connect to the database. Another potential knock-on effect
is that Rails clients could fail their readiness checks for extended periods during a deployment, leading to saturation of
the older nodes.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max_over_time(pgbouncer_used_clients{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m])
      /
      30000
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: pgbouncer_client_conn_replicas component saturation: PGBouncer Client Connections per Process (Replicas)

panels.description:
pgbouncer sync connection pool Saturation per database node, for replica database connections.

Web/api/git applications use a separate connection pool to sidekiq.

When this resource is saturated, web/api database operations may queue, leading to rails worker
saturation and 503 errors in the web.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_pools_server_active_connections{user=~"gitlab|gitlab-registry", database=~"gitlabhq_registry|gitlabhq_production", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m]) +
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_pools_server_testing_connections{user=~"gitlab|gitlab-registry", database=~"gitlabhq_registry|gitlabhq_production", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m]) +
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_pools_server_used_connections{user=~"gitlab|gitlab-registry", database=~"gitlabhq_registry|gitlabhq_production", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m]) +
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_pools_server_login_connections{user=~"gitlab|gitlab-registry", database=~"gitlabhq_registry|gitlabhq_production", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m])
      )
      / on(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) group_left()
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) (
        avg_over_time(pgbouncer_databases_pool_size{name=~"gitlabhq_registry|gitlabhq_production", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: pgbouncer_sync_replica_pool component saturation: Postgres Sync (Web/API/Git) replica Connection Pool Utilization per Node

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in a shard of a
service fleet. If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the
shard needs horizontal or vertical scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, shard) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: shard_cpu component saturation: Average CPU Utilization per Shard

panels.description:
Average CPU utilization per Node.

If average CPU is saturated, it may indicate that a fleet is in need to horizontal or vertical scaling. It may also indicate
imbalances in load in a fleet.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg without(cpu, mode) (1 - rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="patroni-ci"}[5m]))
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)
